CARDINAL . The relevant findings of ORG for the Prevention of Torture and Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment ( “ the ORG ” ) read as follows :
“ A. Institutions of ORG

In so far as the conditions of detention in the police establishments are concerned , it appears that this is the field in which the least progress has been achieved . It is not necessary to enumerate here in detail all the shortcomings observed by the delegation , which are more or less the same as those observed during past visits ( and of which ORG is perfectly aware ) . ... Numerous persons are still detained overnight in police establishments , in cells which should not be used to detain persons for TIME . It is high time to remedy these problems , in particular by placing accused persons under the supervision of institutions of ORG and building new prisons corresponding to ORG standards and to the norms laid down by the NORP legislation .

CARDINAL . Persons placed on remand should as a rule be detained in prisons under the authority of ORG . However , such persons may continue to be held in police temporary detention facilities ( izolatoare de detenţie preventivă , abbreviated “ ORG ” ) under the authority of ORG , if this is required for the purposes of the criminal investigation or if the transfer to a pre - trial establishment can not be effected promptly . It is also possible for remand prisoners to be transferred back from prison to an ORG when necessary for the purposes of the investigation or the court proceedings , for periods of DATE at a time .

At the time of the DATE visit , the delegation noted that the average length of stay in IDPs of persons remanded in custody had decreased . For example , at the ORG of ORG in PERSON , the majority of persons who had been remanded in custody were being transferred to Prison No . CARDINAL within DATE . This is a welcome development . Nevertheless , the delegation also gathered evidence of persons remanded in custody spending extended periods of time in IDPs ( e.g. uninterrupted stays of DATE at PERSON ; DATE at ORG in GPE ) . As regards the practice of repeated transfers of remand prisoners between prisons and IDPs , it continued unabated .

As stressed by the ORG in the past , IDPs will never be capable of providing conditions of detention suited for holding persons remanded in custody . The NORP authorities are well aware of the limitations of the existing IDPs and , following a decision to transfer the responsibility for these facilities to ORG by DATE , have been exploring the possibility of constructing CARDINAL new remand prisons in different regions of the country . During the DATE visit , the delegation was informed that this project was still at the conception phase , due to the lack of budgetary resources . ORG was approaching various donors , banks and the public sector in the hope of raising the necessary funding ( estimated at MONEY per remand prison ) .

The ORG calls upon the NORP authorities to give the highest priority to the implementation of the decision to transfer the responsibility for persons remanded in custody to ORG . The objective should be to end completely the practice of holding remand prisoners in police establishments . The return of remand prisoners to police facilities , for whatever purpose , should be sought and authorised only when there is absolutely no other alternative , and for the shortest time possible .

CARDINAL . NORP In previous visit reports , the ORG recommended that administrative arrest be no longer exploited by operational police officers to detain and question persons suspected of criminal offences , without their being offered the safeguards inherent in the criminal procedure . Nevertheless , during the DATE visit , the delegation came across a number of persons who were officially being held in IDPs for having committed administrative offences ( e.g. at ORG and ORG in PERSON ) , but were in fact being questioned as criminal suspects , apparently without being allowed to contact a lawyer . Resolute steps should be taken to stamp out this abusive practice , which amounts to circumventing the legal provisions concerning the length of police custody in respect of criminal suspects . The ORG reiterates its previous recommendation that firm instructions be issued to law enforcement officials that persons suspected of criminal offences are to be held and questioned strictly in accordance with the provisions of LAW . ORG also calls upon the NORP authorities to ensure that compliance with this requirement is closely supervised .
CARDINAL . Conditions of detention
a. temporary detention facilities ( IDPs )

CARDINAL . Following the ORG ’s visit in DATE , the GPE authorities launched a programme for improving material conditions in IDPs , with a view to implementing the ORG ’s recommendations . However , it became clear from the discussions held with ORG officials at the outset of the DATE visit that the programme had not progressed as rapidly as envisaged , due to the lack of funding . At CARDINAL of the establishments visited , the ORG in ORG , the refurbishment had been suspended , and it was unclear when the works would be finished . That said , the delegation was pleased to note that the ORG envisaged occupancy levels once the refurbishment had been completed would be in accordance with the ORG ’s standards ( i.e. cells measuring some CARDINAL m² would hold CARDINAL persons each ) , and that the in - cell toilets would be partitioned off .

CARDINAL . Despite the above - mentioned programme , conditions of detention in the IDPs visited remained , in general , very poor . The cells had either no windows ( e.g. at the ORG of ORG in GPE , some of the cells at GPE ORG , one cell at PERSON ORG ) or their windows were covered by shutters which substantially limited access to natural light . As for artificial lighting , it was , as a rule , dim . Further , the delegation came across several cells which were very small ( CARDINAL m² at ORG ; CARDINAL m² at PERSON ) . Cells of such a size are only suitable for short periods of detention .

CARDINAL . To sum up , the conditions prevailing at the IDPs visited continue to render them unsuitable for accommodating persons deprived of their liberty for prolonged periods of time ( which continues to be case of both persons remanded in custody and administrative detainees ) . Reference has already been made in paragraph CARDINAL to the envisaged transfer of responsibility for IDPs to ORG and the setting up new remand prisons , which should correspond to the requirements of NORP legislation and the ORG ’s standards . In the meantime , the GPE authorities should redouble their efforts to find the financial means necessary for providing for the fundamental needs and preserving the dignity of detained persons . In particular , urgent steps should be taken to ensure that :

The ORG also recommends that steps be taken to provide some form of activity in addition to outdoor exercise to persons held in excess of DATE at IDPs . ”

During the DATE visit , the delegation observed that the practice of holding remand prisoners in police temporary detention facilities ( izolatoare de detenţie preventivă , abbreviated “ ORG ” ) continued unabated . In the report on the DATE visit , the ORG called upon the GPE authorities to give the highest priority to the implementation of the decision to transfer the responsibility for persons remanded in custody to ORG . However , at DATE visit , the Minister of Justice indicated that the responsibility for the IDPs could not be taken over by his Ministry because conditions of detention in these facilities were substandard .

The ORG shares the view that IDPs do not offer suitable conditions for holding persons remanded in custody . ORG would nevertheless like to stress that , in the interests of the prevention of ill - treatment , the sooner a criminal suspect passes into the hands of a custodial authority which is functionally and institutionally separate from the police , the better . The delegation ’s findings from the DATE visit support that ; most cases of alleged police ill - treatment in the context of the DATE events had emerged only after the persons concerned had been transferred to an establishment under ORG or released . The ORG recommends that , pending the building of new pre - trial establishments , the GPE authorities take steps to transfer the responsibility for IDPs to ORG . Further , the ORG would like to receive up - to - date information on progress made to build new pre - trial establishments under ORG .

CARDINAL . NORP The legal framework for deprivation of liberty of administrative detainees is provided by LAW , which entered into force after the DATE events , on DATE , and replaced LAW . According to the new legal provisions , the persons concerned may be sentenced to DATE of deprivation of liberty , a period which may be extended to DATE if they have committed CARDINAL offence .

In the past , the ORG repeatedly recommended that detention for administrative offences no longer be exploited by operational police officers in order to detain and question persons suspected of criminal offences , without their being offered the safeguards inherent in the criminal procedure . The delegation ’s findings from the DATE visit suggest that such abusive practices were widespread in the context of the DATE events . The ORG is therefore pleased to note that the new LAW restricts the powers of the police to hold persons , on their own authority , for TIME . However , the delegation heard some recent allegations from detained persons that proceedings under LAW ( for insulting law enforcement officials , for instance ) had been initiated against them after they had refused to confess to a criminal offence , despite their correct behaviour vis - à - vis the police , and that their objections had little weight before prosecutors and judges . The lack of access to a lawyer in practice , at this stage of the procedure , had exacerbated this situation . The ORG recommends that prosecutors and judges be encouraged to be particularly vigilant as to the possible exploitation by the police of the provisions of LAW to circumvent the length of police custody in respect of criminal suspects . Reference is also made to paragraph CARDINAL as regards access to a lawyer .

According to LAW , persons under administrative arrest by virtue of LAW should be detained , as a minimum , in conditions provided for sentenced prisoners placed under an “ initial ” regime in penitentiary establishments . That said , it appeared during the DATE visit that a number of persons under arrest continued to serve their administrative sentences in police establishments , which certainly do not offer such conditions . The ORG recommends that the GPE authorities take all the necessary measures to ensure that persons under administrative arrest serve their sentences in penitentiary establishments .

“ Police custody

CARDINAL . Notwithstanding some measures taken by the ORG , many persons in police custody complained about the quality and quantity of the food , although some said that it had slightly improved . Detainees in some police stations ( e.g. PERSON ) indicated that they received food only once per day . Lack of access to medical care was another major concern . Some of the cells were not equipped with mattresses and persons in police custody were not given blankets to sleep on .

CARDINAL . The Special Rapporteur received consistent allegations that the minimum time required by national law for exercise ( TIME per day ) is not respected in many cases . In their reply to the above - quoted report , the NORP authorities acknowledged the seriousness of the problem of ensuring appropriate conditions of detention in GPE and stated that most of the necessary legislative measures had already been taken . The lack of financing for implementing the measures decided upon was the single most serious impediment to solving the problem .

“ Conditions of detention

CARDINAL . The ORG welcomes the amendment in DATE of LAW , which reduced minimum and maximum penalties , prompted a general review of penalties and reoffending , and provided for alternatives to detention , thus contributing to the reduction in the total number of prison population in the State party . ORG also welcomes reconstruction , repairs and maintenance work carried out in a number of penitentiary institutions starting from DATE . Despite ORG efforts to improve the conditions of detention , the ORG remains concerned at overcrowding in certain facilities and that conditions remain harsh , with insufficient ventilation and lighting , poor sanitation and hygiene facilities and inadequate access to healthcare . ORG should :
